	I believe you are looking at a group of farmers/townsmen (or perhaps a 
tr=
oupe of entertainers) dressed up and posed for a photo by a European 
photo=
grapher. None are wearing two swords, symbol of the Bushi class, 
they are =
wearing brightly patterned expensive looking Hakama and 
kimono, like a dai=
myo might wear, yet none of them seem to possess the 
dignity one would exp=
ect of persons of that class. Men and women are 
mixed together but without=
 anything to indicate their status in the 
group or with whom they might be=
 associated (women were more like 
possessions in those days so one would e=
xpect a female to stand 
respectfully behind her father or husband while he=
 was seated or in 
some other way indicate her place in the group). A woman=
 of good 
breeding would never expose that much skin or any hint of her 
un=
derclothes in so public a display as a photograph.
	To me at least this is =
not a photograph of samurai but one of many 
posed photos taken by photogra=
phers like Beato and others who were in 
Japan just after the fall of the S=
hogun...
-t
